content.text:
Using the figure, which two groups will form a strong ionic bond? <image 1>

A. Group 1 and Group 17
B. Group 1 and Group 14
C. Group 14 and Group 18
D. Group 1 and Group 18

To determine which groups will form a strong ionic bond, we need to consider the type of bond formed between the atoms in the atoms of the elements in each group.

- Group 1 (alkali metals) consists of elements like lithium (Li), sodium (Na), and potassium (K). These elements have a full outer electron shell (8 electrons) and do not form ionic bonds.
- Group 14 (alkali earth metals) consists of elements like lithium (Li), sodium (Na), and potassium (K). These elements also have a full outer electron shell (8 electrons) and do not form ionic bonds.
- Group 17 (alkali metals) consists of elements like lithium (Li), sodium (Na), and potassium (K). These elements have a full outer electron shell (8 electrons) and do not form ionic bonds.
- Group 18 (alkali metals) consists of elements like lithium (Li), sodium (Na), and potassium (K). These elements have a full outer electron shell (8 electrons) and do not form ionic bonds.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. Group 1 and Group 18
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
